contentfulBlogPost.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Case Data

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jennifer Clyde is a data quality and data entry shift lead at the COVID Tracking Project.
Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID-19 Testing Data Is Getting Better

lede.lede: The federal government improved its state and county-level COVID-19 PCR testing data since we analyzed it in February. Here’s an update on those changes and what we hope to see next for the data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Alice Goldfarb leads The COVID Tracking Project’s part in The COVID Racial Data Tracker, and is a Nieman Visiting Fellow.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: What We Know About Race and Ethnicity Data

lede.lede: Publicly available federal race and ethnicity COVID-19 data is currently usable and improving, although it shares many of the problems we’ve found in state-reported data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: How Not to Interpret COVID-19 Data

lede.lede: Beware of dating schemes, data dumps, weather events and other issues that can lead to mistakes that confuse the public.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: How to Find Data

lede.lede: Here’s where and how you can find COVID-19 data now that The COVID Tracking Project has ended.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Zach Lipton is a San Francisco software developer and Data Infrastructure co-lead for the COVID Tracking Project.
Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data in a Single Stream

lede.lede: We’ve created a bit of code that helps combine federal testing, case, deaths, and hospitalization data into a single spreadsheet.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

Catherine Pollack is a third year PhD candidate in the Quantitative Biomedical Sciences program at Dartmouth College. Her dissertation research combines data science, epidemiology, and public policy to combat online health misinformation.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Hospitalization Numbers

lede.lede: Here’s a walkthrough of the Department of Health and Human Services’ dataset and what you should know about it.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jennifer Clyde is a data quality and data entry shift lead at the COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Case Data

lede.lede: Here’s a walkthrough of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) daily case dataset and what you should know about it.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: Where to Find Simple COVID-19 Data for the US

lede.lede: As The COVID Tracking Project approaches its final day of data compilation on March 7, 2021, we are recommending a selection of federal data sources to people who want a quick and easy way to keep an eye on the pandemic.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Joseph Bensimon is a member of the COVID Tracking Project’s Data Quality team.
Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Death Numbers

lede.lede: The CDC provides two different datasets regarding COVID-19 fatalities. Here’s a walkthrough of how they compare to each other and to The COVID Tracking Project’s data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Artis Curiskis is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.
Kara Oehler is outreach & reporting co-lead at the COVID Tracking Project and collaboratively runs the CTP special projects Long-Term Care COVID Tracker and City Data.
Aarushi Sahejpal is a Shift Lead on Long-Term Care and City Data at the COVID Tracking Project. She also studies International Relations & Data Science at American University
Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with CMS Nursing Home Data

lede.lede: Here’s what we know about the only federal dataset on COVID-19 outcomes in long-term care facilities.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Testing Data

lede.lede: At least three different federal agencies share testing data for SARS-CoV-2 in at least four different places. Here’s a little about where that data comes from, what each dataset has to offer, and how you can use the datasets best in light of their large differences from state-provided data.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Rachel Glickhouse is a New York-based journalist who works on project management and impact tracking at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Learn More About Using Federal COVID-19 Data with The COVID Tracking Project

lede.lede: In February and March, we’ll hold a series of free trainings to help anyone who uses our data to understand existing federal numbers.

blogContent.raw: {"nodeType":"document","data":{},"content":[{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Before COVID-19, public health departments were already reporting nationally notifiable disease ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"case data","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://wwwn.cdc.gov/nndss/conditions/notifiable/2020/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" (i.e., diseases that are required by law to be reported to government authorities for the purpose of disease monitoring and outbreak detection) to the CDC using the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"National Notifiable Diseases Surveillance System","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://wwwn.cdc.gov/nndss/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". However, the novel SARS-CoV-2 virus and the urgency of a global pandemic created the need for ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"daily ","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"counts of cases and deaths that could be reported publicly on a national level. To produce a more expedient dataset, the CDC created a “","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"robust, multistep process to collect data and confirm the case and death numbers with jurisdictions daily","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/covid-data/faq-surveillance.html"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":".”","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The dataset has included both confirmed and probable cases of COVID-19 since The Council for State and Territorial Epidemiologists issued an ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"April 5, 2020","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://wwwn.cdc.gov/nndss/conditions/coronavirus-disease-2019-covid-19/case-definition/2020/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", Interim Case Definition (","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"revised August 5th 2020","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://wwwn.cdc.gov/nndss/conditions/coronavirus-disease-2019-covid-19/case-definition/2020/08/05/"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":") in which they noted that “field investigations will involve evaluations of persons with no symptoms and these individuals will need to be counted as cases” and then laid out the criteria for determining a confirmed or probable case. We won’t discuss case definitions in detail here, but will write more about them in an upcoming post. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Two levels of detail","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The CDC publishes two main types of case data: aggregate and line level. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Aggregate data","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" includes the total numbers of cases by jurisdiction, as well as totals for confirmed and probable cases where available. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Line-level data","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" includes a de-identified line for each case with detailed demographic data. The aggregate data is updated daily, while the line-level data is only updated monthly due to its complexity. We’re going to cover the aggregate dataset (","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"United States COVID-19 Cases and Deaths by State over Time","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://data.cdc.gov/Case-Surveillance/United-States-COVID-19-Cases-and-Deaths-by-State-o/9mfq-cb36"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":") and only touch briefly on the line-level data, which is generally used in advanced epidemiological research.The sections of the dataset that cover deaths data will be addressed in a separate post in our ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Federal COVID Data 101","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/analysis-updates/category/federal-covid-data-101"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" series.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"How close are the numbers? Very close.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"2QQUDCTvM79O6k9gvoT50k","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Our comparisons of COVID Tracking Project and CDC data for the 56 US states and territories we capture data for show that the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"CDC cases data is extremely similar to the state-reported data we have been capturing.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" (The CDC data also captures the additional jurisdictions of New York City, and three independent countries in compacts of free association with the United States.)","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-inline","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"4pI7b4tfMTuZBr2lbBdAgc","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In our comparison analysis, we found that the total cases in 40 states match exactly; 10 additional states match exactly when offset by one day (i.e. the CDC data is one day ahead of the state reported data), and the remaining six jurisdictions only deviate by up to 5 percent.","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-inline","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"3tgG0TJd7wb15c4KoysIKe","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" In addition to these matches at the total cases level, 25 states and territories exactly match across all three metrics we compared: total, confirmed, and probable cases. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"1mpfZjc6WJKoGguW696Y9K","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Of the states and territories that do not match exactly with or without a one-day offset, three (Guam, New York, and Oklahoma) differ by one percent or less—differences likely caused by slight timing variations in data collection, or differences in backfills done by the state versus those done by the CDC, or both. We have identified the source of the differences in the remaining three jurisdictions: Hawaii’s probable cases are not included in the CDC data; probable case numbers for Massachusetts have been frozen in the CDC data since September 7, 2020; and the CDC is counting four cases in American Samoa, while we have not counted these cases (from what we can tell ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"they were all","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.rnz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/430325/covid-infected-ship-in-american-samoa-to-remain-offshore"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" sailors who came to American Samoa, and were ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"not allowed to leave their ships","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.rnz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/433288/covid-19-positive-sailor-in-american-samoa-port"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"). We have notified these jurisdictions of our findings, and we hope that they will be able to resolve these differences between the state and federal data.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Which case metrics are reported in the two datasets","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"States and territories can report up to three case metrics: total cases, confirmed cases, and probable cases. Every jurisdiction reports total cases in both state and CDC data, but confirmed and probable cases are not always reported in the same way on state dashboards as they are by the CDC. For 34 states or territories, the same case metrics—although not necessarily the same case ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"numbers","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"—appear in the state and federal data. In the remaining states and territories, confirmed cases are reported differently in state and federal reporting for 21 states, while probable cases are reported differently in state and federal reporting for only six states.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"2zWrAVpKWtdvmthM9YJU3q","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"It’s possible many of these differences will be definitional: that is, states and territories may refer to  cases as “confirmed” or “probable” in their public reporting, but those definitions don’t always match the CSTE criteria mentioned above. It’s also possible that it has nothing to do with the definitions, and is a problem in the reporting process—since we don’t have direct access to the reporting from state governments to the federal government, we can’t ascertain what might be happening there. The good news is the CDC does have access to that back-end data stream, and there are encouraging signs that ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"the federal government is working toward releasing more data and more metadata","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/analysis-updates/covid-tracking-project-end-march-7"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". In some cases, the CDC data already provides more information than the state-reported data, such as in Kansas, where the state only posts a total case number, but the CDC publishes a confirmed and probable case breakdown. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Additionally—and importantly for data users—in 11 states or territories, the CDC isn’t reporting probable cases in the expected data field. The CDC dataset contains two columns related to probable cases: ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"prob_cases","marks":[{"type":"code"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" defined as the “total probable cases” and the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"pnew_case","marks":[{"type":"code"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" field defined as the “number of new probable cases.” We would expect to see values in ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"pnew_case","marks":[{"type":"code"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" only when values are also present in ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"prob_cases","marks":[{"type":"code"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". However in Arkansas, Florida, Guam, Iowa, Louisiana, Minnesota, New Hampshire, South Dakota, Texas, Vermont, and Washington, probable values are only available in ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"pnew_case","marks":[{"type":"code"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". In each of these states the sum of ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"pnew_case","marks":[{"type":"code"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" matches the total of probable cases reported by the state.","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-inline","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"5O36DMDhEBt5yc0kcUXlKI","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Based on our conversations with officials in some of these states, it appears that for the majority—or perhaps all—of the states in this category, the data is reported in this way because those states did not initially grant the CDC permission to publicly report their confirmed and probable case breakdown, and then did not update their permissions when they started reporting confirmed and probable breakdowns in public. ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"Again, the good news here is that this can be fixed quite easily with a little more coordination between state and federal governments.","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"What’s missing","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"One notable absence in this dataset is the lack of data notes and revision history. Data notes that address anomalies (unexpected decreases, data dumps, etc.) in the case data can be found in the downloadable xlsx files of the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Community Profile Reports","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://beta.healthdata.gov/National/COVID-19-Community-Profile-Report/gqxm-d9w9"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", however the notes are not available in a structured format. (For our purposes, “structured” means that each note is associated with the appropriate state and date(s) in fixed fields so that data users can use this information either automatically or manually.) ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Adding structured notes to the dataset would make them easily accessible for data users seeking to contextualize data. It is also currently unclear whether backfills or corrections are ever included in the existing (unstructured) notes, though of course they do happen in the data; we would recommend including these in the notes. We also recommend that the federal government offer a clear record of revisions using a publicly accessible method, which would enhance transparency and help build trust in the federal data.","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Where to find, and how to use, this data","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"This aggregate cases and deaths dataset is used in the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"COVID Data Tracker","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"COVID Data Tracker Weekly Review","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/covid-data/covidview/index.html"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Community Profile Reports","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://beta.healthdata.gov/National/COVID-19-Community-Profile-Report/gqxm-d9w9"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" and ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"State Profile Reports","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://beta.healthdata.gov/browse?tags=covid-19-spr"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":". It is available for download both from ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"the CDC","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://data.cdc.gov/Case-Surveillance/United-States-COVID-19-Cases-and-Deaths-by-State-o/9mfq-cb36"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" and on ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"HealthData.gov","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://beta.healthdata.gov/dataset/United-States-COVID-19-Cases-and-Deaths-by-State-o/hiyb-zgc2"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", in a variety of formats including ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"CSV","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://data.cdc.gov/api/views/9mfq-cb36/rows.csv?accessType=DOWNLOAD"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" and XML. The CSVs are straightforward and easy to work with. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"It is also possible to filter, sort, and visualize the data ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"on the CDC website","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://data.cdc.gov/Case-Surveillance/United-States-COVID-19-Cases-and-Deaths-by-State-o/9mfq-cb36/data"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" without downloading it. You can also ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"query the data online","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://data.cdc.gov/resource/9mfq-cb36.json"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" via the Socrata Open Data API after consulting the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"excellent and comprehensive documentation","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://dev.socrata.com/foundry/data.cdc.gov/9mfq-cb36"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" provided. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"1BNuvgU0aUVUFuY6gtrchU","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"In the dataset, each row corresponds to one state for one day going back to January 2020; the data is updated twice daily, and major disruptions in the data are included in the Community Profile Reports. The data dictionary provided by the CDC is fairly minimal, but clear and adequate for a dataset with only 15 data fields. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block","content":[],"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"5YPyKqlUUzRAKYgMvEp8O","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"For advanced users, there is the previously mentioned line-level data available in two different datasets: the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"COVID-19 Case Surveillance Public Use Data","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://data.cdc.gov/Case-Surveillance/COVID-19-Case-Surveillance-Public-Use-Data/vbim-akqf"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":" and the ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"hyperlink","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"COVID-19 Case Surveillance Restricted Access Detailed Data","marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"data":{}}],"data":{"uri":"https://healthdata.gov/dataset/covid-19-case-surveillance-restricted-access-detailed-data"}},{"nodeType":"text","value":", which—as the name suggests—has to be requested from the CDC and used for specific purposes only. The primary difference between the two datasets is the level of detail: the public use dataset contains 12 additional data fields and the restricted data set includes 32 additional fields. Additional information including FAQs and the data dictionaries can be found linked from the dataset pages. ","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"heading-3","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"The upshot","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Overall, the aggregate federal data is a very good replacement for state reported data, and the divergences we’ve described are not significant blockers to using the aggregate federal dataset now. We’d like to see the federal government provide relevant data notes in a structured way with the dataset, which will allow users to work with the data more responsibly and transparently. Additionally, we hope that going forward, the federal and state governments are able to work more closely together to reconcile the differences in confirmed and probable reporting. But even with these caveats, ","marks":[],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":"the dataset is an excellent successor for COVID Tracking Project’s state-reported case data","marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"text","value":".","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"","marks":[],"data":{}}],"data":{}},{"nodeType":"paragraph","content":[{"nodeType":"text","value":"Additional research and contributions from Michal Mart, Dave Luo, and Peter Walker","marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"data":{}}],"data":{}}]}

image.title: US Daily Reported COVID-19 Cases, 7 day average lines, Mar 1, 2020–Feb 17, 2020
image.description: 2 line charts showing COVID-19 cases over time (7-day average) for the US. One line is CDC data, the other is COVID Tracking Project data. The lines match almost perfectly.

footnote.footnote: For comparison purposes, we added the New York state and city totals together in the CDC data.

In Iowa, where the CTP data does not capture probable cases, there appears to be a large gap between the CDC total cases and CTP total cases. Iowa’s probable cases are currently captured in our data in the “positive antigen tests people” field because we’re missing multiple public time series for Iowa’s COVID-19 metrics that would be required to move these figures into the “probable cases” field. When we interpret the figure for Iowa’s positive antigen tests as probable cases, the case data provided by Iowa on its dashboard matches perfectly to the Iowa data in the CDC dataset.

image.title: COVID Tracking Project Cases Data vs Federal Cases Data
image.description: US cartogram showing which states match exactly between CTP and CDC case data. 40 states match exactly, 10 match with a one-day offset, and 5 states show a difference of less than 5%.

image.title: CTP Cases Data vs Federal Cases Data
image.description: Two Venn Diagrams, showing where (i.e., which states( CTP and CDC report probable and confirmed cases.

footnote.footnote: We are counting the 11 states described here as reporting probable cases only in the CDC’s `pnew_case` field as reporting probable cases to the CDC.

image.title: Guide to accessing the CDC state level Cases and Deaths dataset
image.description: Animated guide to accessing the CDC state level Cases and Deaths dataset at https://data.cdc.gov/Case-Surveillance/United-States-COVID-19-Cases-and-Deaths-by-State-o/9mfq-cb36

table.table:
| CDC Description                                                                              | CDC Column Name | CTP API Field Name |
|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------|--------------------|
| Date of counts                                                                               | `submission_date` | `date`               |
| Date and time record was created                                                             | `created_at`      | `lastUpdatedEt`      |
| Total number of cases                                                                        | `tot_cases`       | `positive`           |
| Total confirmed cases                                                                        | `conf_cases`      | `positiveCasesViral` |
| Total probable cases                                                                         | `prob_cases`      | `probableCases `     |
| Number of new cases                                                                          | `new_case`        | `positiveIncrease`*  |
| Number of new probable cases                                                                 | `pnew_case`       | N/A                |
| Total number of deaths                                                                       | `tot_death`       | `death`              |
| Total number of confirmed deaths                                                             | `conf_death`      | `deathConfirmed`     |
| Total number of probable deaths                                                              | `prob_death`      | `deathProbable`      |
| Number of new deaths                                                                         | `new_death`       | `deathIncrease`*    |
| Number of new probable deaths                                                                | `pnew_death`      | N/A                |
| Jurisdiction                                                                                 | `state`           | `state`              |
| If Agree, then confirmed and probable cases are included. If Not Agree, only total cases.    | `consent_cases`   | N/A                |
| If Agree, then confirmed and probable deaths are included. If Not Agree, only total deeaths. | `pnew_death`      | N/A

references.caption: \* `positiveIncrease` and `death increase` represent the difference from previous day topline metrics rather than actual new cases/deaths on a given day

lede.lede: Here’s a walkthrough of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) daily case dataset and what you should know about it.
